content:
Hey all. @Mara, @Manish Goregaokar, @Aidan Hobson Sayers, and I were doing some meta planning and discussion at the end of the last week. This was in the context of some core team meetings where we were talking about 2021 Edition planning and what the full scope of work looks like. I wanted to try and move that conversation into this channel.

We created a google document with planning -- it kind of duplicates the existing hackmd, but contains a bit of extra notes on milestones and things. It also has some more detailed updates on the likely candidates and other things.

One of the immediate steps that I would like to do is to establish the "viability criteria" and a drop-dead date, probably in the not that distant future (e.g., feb 15). The idea being that in order to be considered for the edition, the viability criteria for an idea must be met.

Our current draft of the 'viability criteria' was:

  • Accepted RFC, or RFC open on repo and “looking good”
  • Migration, idiom lint plan in place
  • Implementation either trivial or underway

(cc @rylev, @Steve Klabnik too)
To circle back to this -- I am preparing a proposed RFC and general plan.
The RFC would describe the 2021 Edition and I would then take it to the core team -- assuming they're on board with the general plan, we'd open the RFC and it would hopefully move quickly.
We should probably setup some kind of planning sync time
The plan is for the edition to be relatively lightweight compared to rust 2018 -- it's not a "major initiative", more of a chance to introduce various changes.
OK, I put in some time into outlining a draft RFC today. I'd appreciate it if folks took a look!
Hey @Steve Klabnik and @simulacrum -- I know we've talked about this a fair bit, curious if that looks kind of like what you expected
It's not a complete first draft yet, but I think the key bits are there
i think broadly this looks great! thank you so much for putting it together
yeah, leaving a few scattered comments directly
Last bullet point in the summary list starts a sentence but never finishes it. "In some cases"

So I started adding some more content -- in particular, I was reviewing RFC 2052 and I found that (for example) its rules about "what makes a good change" for an edition are still relevant and quite well written (naturally, given the author).
Although now I'm wondering whether those more properly belong in a set of lang team edition guidelines
For context, one of the things I'm trying to do in this RFC is to focus on the "core user experience", and leave detailed rule-making to foll0w-up RFCs or policies published by other teams
I'd like to setup a regular sync time, I think, or some kind of cadence here
I've been a bit distracted but I want to get this effort "back on track"
